title: Can you solve the magical maze riddle? - Alex Rosenthal

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To cast a forgetting curse on the competitors.

What was the minimum number of events that the tournament could have had, based on the total points earned?

options.label: A
options.text: First place received 1 point, second place received 2 points, and third place received 3 points.

options.label: B
options.text: First place received more points than second, and second received more points than third.

options.label: C
options.text: First place received 5 points, second place received 2 points, and third place received 1 point.

options.label: D
options.text: First place received 7 points, second place received 2 points, and third place received 1 point.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It won all four events except one.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why is measles so contagious?

multiple-choice.question: What does the term "contagious" mean to epidemiologists?

options.label: A
options.text: A disease that is easily spread through the air.

options.label: B
options.text: A disease that is highly infectious and can be spread through various means.

options.label: C
options.text: A disease that is not easily spread from person to person.

options.label: D
options.text: A disease that is only spread through direct contact.

multiple-choice.question: What is the average number of people a single sick person infects, known as?

options.label: A
options.text: Basic reproduction number (R0)

options.label: B
options.text: Infectiousness rate

options.label: C
options.text: Contagiousness factor

options.label: D
options.text: Disease spread index

multiple-choice.question: What happens when R0 is less than 1?

options.label: A
options.text: The disease will spread rapidly through the population.

options.label: B
options.text: The disease will eventually die out.

options.label: C
options.text: The disease will become more contagious.

options.label: D
options.text: The disease will become less infectious.

multiple-choice.question: Why is measles considered one of the most contagious diseases?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it has a low R0 value.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is highly infectious and can be spread through the air.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is only spread through direct contact.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not contagious at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main reasons measles is so contagious?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it has a high R0 value.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is not infectious at all.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is extremely infectious and can be spread through the air.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is only spread through direct contact.

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: Why does this flower smell like a dead body? - Daniel Nickrent

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the Rafflesia plant?

options.label: A
options.text: It has the largest leaves in the world.

options.label: B
options.text: It has the biggest and strangest flower in the world.

options.label: C
options.text: It can photosynthesize on its own.

options.text: It is the only plant that can live underwater.

options.label: C

options.text: The carrion flies that pollinate it.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To communicate with other Rafflesia plants.

title: How does alcohol cause blackouts? - Shannon Odell

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of Dr. Donald Goodwin's study in 1969?

options.label: A
options.text: To investigate the effects of alcohol on motor skills.

options.label: B
options.text: To study the impact of alcohol on memory and decision-making.

options.label: C
options.text: To examine the relationship between alcohol consumption and cognitive function.

options.label: D
options.text: To analyze the effects of alcohol on emotional regulation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary chemical compound responsible for the effects of alcohol on the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Ethanol

options.label: B
options.text: Methanol

options.label: C
options.text: Acetaldehyde

options.label: D
options.text: Propylene glycol

multiple-choice.question: How does ethanol interact with receptors in the brain, leading to impaired memory?

options.label: A
options.text: By activating receptors and increasing neuronal firing.

options.label: B
options.text: By blocking receptors and reducing neuronal communication.

options.label: C
options.text: By altering the structure of receptors and disrupting long-term potentiation.

options.label: D
options.text: By reducing the release of neurotransmitters and impairing synaptic plasticity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called that is thought to depend on the transfer of moment-to-moment understanding to something we can remember?

options.label: A
options.text: Long-term potentiation (LTP)

options.label: B
options.text: Short-term memory consolidation

options.label: C
options.text: Memory encoding

options.label: D
options.text: Synaptic plasticity

multiple-choice.question: At what BAC level is a blackout typically thought to occur?

options.label: A
options.text: Approximately 0.08

options.label: B
options.text: Approximately 0.12

options.label: C
options.text: Approximately 0.16

options.label: D
options.text: Approximately 0.20

title: The real reason dodo birds went extinct - Leon Claessens

multiple-choice.question: What was the origin of the dodo species?

options.label: A
options.text: They were created by humans through genetic engineering.

options.label: B
options.text: They migrated from Europe to Mauritius.

options.label: C
options.text: Tropical pigeons from Southeast Asia migrated across the Indian Ocean and eventually settled on the remote archipelago east of Madagascar, where they evolved into a distinct species.

options.label: D
options.text: They were native to Mauritius and had no ancestors.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the dodo's flight muscles shrink?

options.label: A
options.text: They were too large for their body size.

options.label: B
options.text: They were not needed because there were no predators on the island.

options.label: C
options.text: They were damaged in a natural disaster.

options.label: D
options.text: They were affected by climate change.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the dodo's extinction?

options.label: A
options.text: Overhunting by humans.

options.label: B
options.text: Invasive species such as macaques, goats, pigs, and rats were introduced to the island by humans, leading to competition for resources and predation of dodo eggs and chicks.

options.label: C
options.text: Climate change and natural disasters.

options.label: D
options.text: The dodo's brain size was too small.

multiple-choice.question: What was the role of macaques, goats, pigs, and rats in the dodo's extinction?

options.label: A
options.text: They helped to protect the dodo from other predators.

options.label: B
options.text: They competed with the dodo for resources and preyed on dodo eggs and chicks.

options.label: C
options.text: They had no impact on the dodo's population.

options.label: D
options.text: They were a food source for the dodo.

multiple-choice.question: Why were dodos often misrepresented in the past?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were rare and difficult to study.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were seen as a threat to humans.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were often depicted in artistic renderings that were exaggerated or inaccurate, and because they were framed as inept, clumsy, lazy, and unfit for survival in scholarly works and popular media.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were seen as a symbol of human power and control.

title: Would you raise the baby that ate your siblings? - Francesca Barbero

multiple-choice.question: What is the Alcon blue butterfly's unique life cycle, and how does it interact with ants?

options.label: A
options.text: The Alcon blue butterfly lays eggs on a leaf, and the caterpillar hatches to eat the leaf.

options.label: B
options.text: The Alcon blue butterfly lays eggs on a wildflower, and the caterpillar hatches to infiltrate an ant colony.

options.label: C
options.text: The Alcon blue butterfly lays eggs on a tree, and the caterpillar hatches to climb the tree.

options.label: D
options.text: The Alcon blue butterfly lays eggs on a rock, and the caterpillar hatches to burrow underground.

multiple-choice.question: How does the Alcon blue caterpillar disguise itself to the ants, and what happens as a result?

options.label: A
options.text: The caterpillar secretes a chemical that smells like the ants' own pheromones, and the ants feed it and protect it.

options.label: B
options.text: The caterpillar secretes a thread of silk and descends to the ground, where it is picked up by an ant and taken into the nest.

options.label: C
options.text: The caterpillar makes noises that sound like those emitted by the ant queens, and the nurse ants feed it extra food.

options.label: D
options.text: The caterpillar arches its body in a begging posture to obtain more food, and the nurse ants regurgitate food into its mouth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the sugary secretions produced by the Alcon blue caterpillar, and how do the ants respond?

options.label: A
options.text: The secretions are used to communicate with the ants, and the ants respond by feeding the caterpillar more food.

options.label: B
options.text: The secretions are used to manipulate the ants' behavior, inhibiting their movement and making them more protective and aggressive.

options.label: C
options.text: The secretions are used to attract the ants, and the ants respond by rescuing the caterpillar from predators.

options.label: D
options.text: The secretions are used to signal to the ants that the caterpillar is royalty, and the nurse ants feed it extra food.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the Alcon blue butterfly and the parasitoid wasps that target it?

options.label: A
options.text: The butterfly is the host of the wasp, and the wasp lays eggs on the butterfly's body.

options.label: B
options.text: The wasp is the host of the butterfly, and the butterfly lays eggs on the wasp's body.

options.label: C
options.text: The butterfly and the wasp are mutualistic, and they work together to produce a beneficial chemical.

options.label: D
options.text: The butterfly and the wasp are parasitic, and they both lay eggs on the same host ant.

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of small environmental changes on the populations of parasitic butterflies like the Alcon blue?

options.label: A
options.text: Environmental changes have no impact on the populations of parasitic butterflies.

options.label: B
options.text: Environmental changes lead to an increase in the populations of parasitic butterflies.

options.label: C
options.text: Environmental changes lead to a decrease in the populations of parasitic butterflies.

options.label: D
options.text: Environmental changes lead to a complex relationship between the butterfly and its host ants.

title: How to know if you're being selfish (and whether or not that's bad) - Mark Hopwood

multiple-choice.question: According to German philosopher Immanuel Kant, what is the motivation behind human actions, even when they seem to be for the sake of others?

options.text: A deep sense of altruism

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A desire for social status

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

options.label: B
options.text: John Stuart Mill

options.label: C
options.text: Aristotle

options.label: D
options.text: Thomas Hobbes

options.label: A
options.text: Moral duty

options.label: B
options.text: Emotions like pity and sympathy

options.label: C
options.text: Love

options.label: D
options.text: A desire for social status

multiple-choice.question: According to Iris Murdoch, what is the definition of love that can help us overcome selfishness?

options.label: A
options.text: The act of giving to others without expectation of reward

options.label: B
options.text: The extremely difficult realization that something other than oneself is real

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to see the world from another person's perspective

options.label: D
options.text: The desire to be liked and admired by others

multiple-choice.question: According to Iris Murdoch, what practice can help us cultivate attention and direct it beyond the self?

options.label: A
options.text: Engaging in social media

options.label: B
options.text: Practicing mindfulness meditation

options.label: C
options.text: Engaging with art, learning foreign languages, or observing the natural environment

options.label: D
options.text: Reading self-help books

title: When AI can fake reality, who can you trust? - Sam Gregory

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main problem with deepfakes?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too realistic.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too easy to detect.

options.label: C
options.text: They are being used to harm people and undermine trust in information.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too expensive to create.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's organization, WITNESS, working on to address the issue of deepfakes?

options.label: A
options.text: A new type of AI that can detect deepfakes.

options.label: B
options.text: A global effort to "Prepare, Don't Panic" and fortify the truth of critical frontline journalists and human-rights defenders.

options.label: C
options.text: A new social media platform that is immune to deepfakes.

options.label: D
options.text: A new type of deepfake that is more realistic.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's proposal for ensuring that detection tools are in the hands of the people who need them?

options.label: A
options.text: Making detection tools available to anyone on the internet.

options.label: B
options.text: Ensuring that detection tools are available to journalists, community leaders, and election officials globally, with attention to real-world accessibility and use.

options.label: C
options.text: Developing new AI models that can detect deepfakes.

options.label: D
options.text: Creating a new type of social media platform that is immune to deepfakes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker proposing as a way to add transparency to AI-generated media?

options.label: A
options.text: Invisible watermarking to AI-generated media.

options.label: B
options.text: Cryptographically signed metadata to files, which provides details about the content, including how AI was used to create or edit it.

options.label: C
options.text: A new type of AI that can detect deepfakes.

options.label: D
options.text: A new social media platform that is immune to deepfakes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker warning against in terms of the consequences of not taking steps to address the issue of deepfakes?

options.label: A
options.text: A world where it gets easier to create deepfakes.

options.label: B
options.text: A world where it gets easier to dismiss reality as potentially faked.

options.label: C
options.text: A world where people are no longer able to believe anything.

options.label: D
options.text: A world where people are no longer able to think or judge.

title: History vs. Egypt’s "most powerful" pharaoh - Jessica Tomkins

multiple-choice.question: Who reigned as Pharaoh of Egypt for almost 70 years in the 13th century BCE?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: It was a decisive victory for Ramesses II

options.label: B
options.text: It was a stalemate in which Ramesses II's arrogance almost cost Egypt the war

options.label: C
options.text: It was a peace treaty that marked the beginning of Ramesses II's prosperous reign

options.text: It was a battle in which the Hittites were defeated

options.label: A
options.text: To showcase Egypt's strength and discourage a Nubian revolution

options.label: B
options.text: To build a temple for the gods

options.label: C
options.text: To create a monument to himself

options.label: D
options.text: To commemorate a military victory

multiple-choice.question: How did Ramesses II treat the monuments and temples built by previous pharaohs?

options.label: A
options.text: He restored and preserved them

options.label: B
options.text: He tore down existing temples to reuse their bricks in monuments to himself

options.label: C
options.text: He left them untouched

options.label: D
options.text: He added to them

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the fact that Ramesses II ruled for almost seven decades?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that he was a wise and just ruler

title: The unbelievable science of how we read

options.text: Because the font used is not designed for readability.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the letters are not aligned properly.

options.label: C
options.text: Because letters with rounded tops have to be slightly taller than letters with flat tops to appear the same size.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the letters are being displayed on a small screen.

options.label: D

options.text: By scanning the letters from left to right one by one.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: By recognizing the literal shape of the word.

options.label: D
options.text: By sounding out the letters or combinations of letters in the order they appear.

options.label: C
options.text: Peripheral vision

options.label: D
options.text: Retina

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Enough to recognize the word and sense how long the next word or two is.

options.label: D
options.text: Enough to recognize the word and skip over the next few words.

title: TED Explores: A New Climate Vision

multiple-choice.question: Christiana Figueres mentions that there's a "race between two exponential curves" in relation to climate change. What does she mean by this?

options.label: B
options.text: A comparison between the rate of climate change and the rate of technological progress.

options.label: D
options.text: A challenge between two opposing views on climate change.

multiple-choice.question: According to Julio Friedmann, what is the potential vision of the future that could get people excited about the energy transition and solving climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: A world where everything remains the same, but is clean and sustainable.

options.label: B
options.text: A world where abundant, sustainable, and cheap energy is available to everyone.

options.label: C
options.text: A world where technology has solved all our problems, but at a high cost.

options.label: D
options.text: A world where humans have abandoned their dependence on energy.

multiple-choice.question: Anika Goss mentions that Detroit's past has been marked by economic inequality and segregation. What is one way that the city is trying to address this issue?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: By increasing access to education and healthcare in low-income neighborhoods.

multiple-choice.question: Jim and Jessica Whitaker mention that their farm in Arkansas has seen a significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and water use. What is one way that they achieved this?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By experimenting with new methods of planting seeds and irrigating less.

options.label: C
options.text: By adopting less labor-intensive ways of planting seeds and using less water.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a combination of all the above methods.

multiple-choice.question: According to the experts, what would a future where we have achieved our climate goals look like?

options.label: A
options.text: A world where everyone has access to abundant, clean energy and the economy is thriving.

options.label: B
options.text: A world where climate change has been completely eradicated and there are no more natural disasters.

options.label: C
options.text: A world where humans have abandoned their dependence on energy and live in a state of complete sustainability.

options.label: D
options.text: A world where technology has solved all our problems, but at a high cost.

title: What the biggest brain on Earth can do - David Gruber and Shane Gero

options.label: B
options.text: To amplify and direct sound waves

options.text: 270 decibels, 40 decibels away

options.label: D
options.text: 300 decibels, 70 decibels away
